data.title: 350+ Best Trivia Questions and Answers [2024 Edition]
data.meta_description: Make your next trivia quiz epic with 350+ questions from 15+ categories that both adults and kids will love.
data.text:
Are you a trivia quiz buff? Or maybe you’re looking to create your own trivia quiz? After some thorough research, we’ve come up with the best of the best trivia questions.

There’s 350+ questions in our collection covering a wide range of topics, including food and drink, geography, fashion, and more. We’ve also included easy and hard questions, kid-friendly questions, and general knowledge questions. Can you answer them all? Test your knowledge and find out.

Trivia Question Categories

These are the trivia categories we will cover:

Easy trivia questions

Hard trivia questions

Funny trivia questions

General knowledge trivia questions

Kid-friendly trivia questions

Technology & science trivia questions

Pop culture trivia questions

Cars & sports trivia questions

Health & cooking trivia questions

Geography & history trivia questions

Music & literature trivia questions

Fashion & design trivia questions

Law & politics trivia questions

Animal trivia questions

Business trivia questions

Game & riddles trivia questions

Religion & culture trivia questions

Easy Trivia Questions

Get your trivia quiz off to a flying start with this easy list of trivia questions that are perfect for beginners.

Which famous play features a character named Romeo?

Answer: Romeo and Juliet

What is the largest mammal in the world?

Answer: Blue whale

What is the main ingredient in guacamole?

Answer: Avocado

Who is known as the “Father of the United States” and the first President of the country?

Answer: George Washington

Who painted the Mona Lisa?

Answer: Leonardo da Vinci

What popular ice cream flavor is typically made with crushed cookies?

Answer: Cookies and Cream

What is the name of the largest ocean on Earth?

Answer: Pacific Ocean

What famous music group was John Lennon a part of before pursuing a solo career?

Answer: The Beatles

In the story of Snow White, how many dwarfs are there?

Answer: Seven

Who is the king of the gods in Greek mythology?

Answer: Zeus

What do bees collect to make honey?

Answer: Nectar

In what galaxy is our solar system located?

Answer: Milky Way

Which planet is known as the “Blue Planet”?

Answer: Earth

Which geometric shape has four equal sides and four right angles?

Answer: Square

What is the main ingredient in the dish sushi?

Answer: Rice

Hard Trivia Questions

Put your audience to the test with some tougher trivia questions, and see who comes out as the true trivia champion.

What is the capital city of Mongolia?

Answer: Ulaanbaatar

What is the rarest blood type among humans?

Answer: AB-negative

How many wives did King Henry VIII have?

Answer: Six

In which year did Serena Williams win her first Grand Slam singles title?

Answer: 1999 (US Open)

In what year and in which city were the first modern Olympic Games held?

Answer: 1896 in Athens, Greece

What is the specific term used to describe a type of sandstorm characterized by strong winds carrying a wall of dust and sand, reducing visibility and causing hazardous conditions?

Answer: Haboob

Benjamin Franklin was a key figure in the drafting of the United States Constitution. Which state did he represent during the Constitutional Convention in 1787?

Answer: Pennsylvania

Before founding Facebook, Mark Zuckerberg created a website that allowed users to compare the attractiveness of two people side by side. What was the name of this website?

Answer: Facemash

In the early 20th century, a soft drink named “Bib-Label Lithiated Lemon-Lime Soda” was known for containing lithium. Which company later acquired this beverage and transformed it into a popular lemon-lime soft drink we know today?

Answer: Coca-Cola Company (they rebranded it as 7UP)

What is the capital city of Bhutan?

Answer: Thimphu

In mathematics, what is the name for a number that is not a prime number and has more than two factors?

Answer: Composite number

Who is the Greek god of war and son of Zeus and Hera?

Answer: Ares

What is the scientific term for the “little brain” at the base of the brain that coordinates movement and balance?

Answer: Cerebellum

What is the chemical symbol for the element mercury?

Answer: Hg

What is the name of the largest moon of Jupiter?

Answer: Ganymede

Funny Trivia Questions

Give your audience a break from the usual trivia questions with ones that are both unexpected and hilarious.

What is the term for a group of flamingos?

Answer: Flamboyance

What is the only planet that rotates on its side?

Answer: Uranus

What is the world record for the longest hiccupping spree?

A. 68 years

B. 50 years

C. 82 years

Answer: A. 68 years

What is the official animal of Scotland?

Answer: Unicorn

What animal is known to laugh and has been proven to have a sense of humor?

Answer: Rats

What fruit is known as the “king of fruits” and is banned in many hotels and public transportation in Southeast Asia due to its strong smell?

Answer: Durian

What is the fear of clowns called?

Answer: Coulrophobia

What animal’s milk is pink?

Answer: Hippopotamus

What is the northernmost capital city in the world?

Answer: Reykjavik, Iceland

In what year did the Great Fire of London occur?

Answer: 1666

General Knowledge Trivia Game Questions

Looking for a mix of everything? Here’s a comprehensive list of general trivia questions for adults that cover a wide range of topics.

In what year did the Berlin Wall fall?

Answer: 1989

What is the capital city of Brazil?

Answer: Brasília

Who wrote “Pride and Prejudice”?

Answer: Jane Austen

Who is known as the “Father of Modern Physics”?

Answer: Albert Einstein

Which mountain range is the longest in the world?

Answer: The Andes

What is the largest island in the world?

Answer: Greenland

What is the chemical symbol for silver?

Answer: Ag

Who painted “The Persistence of Memory”?

Answer: Salvador Dali

What is the largest bone in the human body?

Answer: Femur

Before becoming President, Barack Obama served as a U.S. Senator from which state?

Answer: Illinois

In which year did the Titanic sink?

Answer: 1912

What is the capital city of Argentina?

Answer: Buenos Aires

Who painted the famous artwork “The Last Supper”?

Answer: Leonardo da Vinci

In which year did World War II end?

Answer: 1945

What is the currency of Japan?

Answer: Japanese Yen

Kid-Friendly Trivia Questions

Engage your students in a lively and educational experience with these exciting kid-friendly trivia game questions. From Disney characters to fascinating facts, these questions are sure to make learning enjoyable and memorable.

What is the name of the little mermaid in the Disney movie?

Answer: Ariel

What animal is known for its long neck and spots on its body?

Answer: Giraffe

What is the name of the toy cowboy in the movie “Toy Story”?

Answer: Woody

What do you call a group of fish?

Answer: School

In what season do leaves fall off the trees?

Answer: Autumn/Fall

How many colors are there in a rainbow?

Answer: Seven

What animal is known for its ability to change color to match its surroundings?

Answer: Chameleon

What animal is known for hopping and has a pouch to carry its young?

Answer: Kangaroo

In what fairy tale does a pumpkin turn into a carriage?

Answer: Cinderella

What animal is known for its long trunk and large ears?

Answer: Elephant

What is the name of Mickey Mouse’s dog?

Answer: Pluto

Which planet is known as the “Red Planet”?

Answer: Mars

What is the main color of the Smurfs?

Answer: Blue

In the nursery rhyme, who had a farm with a dog named BINGO?

Answer: Old MacDonald

Which bird can repeat words and phrases that it hears, often kept as a pet?

Answer: Parrot

Technology & Science Trivia Questions

Technology Trivia Questions

These trivia questions focus on cellular phones, operating systems, the history of the computer, and social media.

What year was the very first model of the iPhone released?

Answer: 2007

What’s the shortcut for the “copy” function on most computers?

Answer: ctrl c

What is often seen as the smallest unit of memory?

Answer: kilobyte

Is Java a type of OS?

Answer: No

Who is often called the father of the computer?

Answer: Charles Babbage

What does “HTTP” stand for?

Answer: HyperText Transfer Protocol

What is the name of the man who launched eBay back in 1995?

Answer: Pierre Omidyar

Which email service is owned by Microsoft?

Answer: Hotmail

Google Chrome, Safari, Firefox, and Explorer are different types of what?

Answer: Web browsers

What was Twitter’s original name?

Answer: twttr

Which programming language is often used for developing Android applications?

Answer: Java

What is the name of the open-source operating system created by Linus Torvalds?

Answer: Linux

In the context of email, what does “CC” stand for?

Answer: Carbon Copy

In computing, what does “CPU” stand for?

Answer: Central Processing Unit

Which company developed the first commercially available computer mouse?

Answer: Xerox

Science Trivia Questions

This part focuses on the weather, planets, and elements. Think you can answer all the trivia questions correctly? Try these questions!

Who discovered penicillin?

Answer: Alexander Fleming

Who was the first woman to win a Nobel Prize (in 1903)?

Answer: Marie Curie

What part of the atom has no electric charge?

Answer: Neutron

What is the symbol for potassium?

Answer: K

What is meteorology the study of?

Answer: The weather

Which planet is the hottest in the solar system?

Answer: Venus

Which natural disaster is measured with a Richter scale?

Answer: Earthquakes

What animals are pearls found in?

Answer: Oysters

Which planet has the most gravity?

Answer: Jupiter

How many molecules of oxygen does ozone have?

Answer: Three

Pop Culture Trivia Questions

Comics Trivia Questions

The following questions cover the two biggest superhero comic houses in the world – Marvel and DC.

What is Hawkeye’s real name?

Answer: Clint Barton

Which Avenger is the only one who could calm the Hulk down?

Answer: Black Widow

Night Crawler, member of the X-Men, has what kind of powers?

Answer: Can teleport

Which infinity stone was located on Vormir?

Answer: Soul Stone

Which original Avenger was not in the first few movies?

Answer: The Wasp

What was Superman’s birth name?

Answer: Kal-El

What is the name of Batman’s butler?

Answer: Alfred

Aquaman is from which city under the sea?

Answer: Atlantis

Who is Green Lantern’s nemesis?

Answer: Sinestro

What does DC stand for?

Answer: Detective Comics

Movies & TV Questions

The trivia game questions are all entertainment-based? Are you a big enough movie and TV fan to answer them all?

What is the name of the song that Queen Elsa sings as she builds her ice castle in the movie Frozen?

Answer: Let It Go

How many films did Sean Connery play James Bond in?

Answer: Seven

Which Indiana Jones movie was released back in 1984?

Answer: Indiana Jones and the Temple of Doom

How many Lord of the Rings films are there?

Answer: Three

What was the name of the actor who played Jack Dawson in Titanic?

Answer: Leonardo DiCaprio

Which popular TV show featured house Targaryen and Stark?

Answer: Game of Thrones

What was the name of the family who starred in 7th Heaven?

Answer: The Camdens

Which cartoon character lives in a pineapple under the sea?

Answer: Spongebob Squarepants

In what year was the first episode of South Park aired?

Answer: 1997

Who won the Academy Award for Best Actor for his role in the 2020 film “Joker”?

Answer: Joaquin Phoenix

In the movie “Forrest Gump,” what famous phrase does Forrest’s mother say life is like?

Answer: “Life is like a box of chocolates; you never know what you’re gonna get.”

Which animated film features a character named Simba and includes the song “Circle of Life”?

Answer: The Lion King

Who directed the 1994 film “Pulp Fiction”?

Answer: Quentin Tarantino

In the movie “The Shawshank Redemption,” what is the name of the main character played by Tim Robbins?

Answer: Andy Dufresne

In the movie “Casablanca,” what famous line does Humphrey Bogart’s character Rick Blaine say to Ilsa Lund, played by Ingrid Bergman?

Answer: “Here’s looking at you, kid.”

Questions About Stars, Celebrities & Influencers

These superstar questions ask about the hottest names in Hollywood and on the internet.

Which actor appeared in films “Face Off” and “Ghost Rider”?

Answer: Nicholas Cage

Who played Wolverine?

Answer: Hugh Jackman

Which actress won the Oscar for Best Actress in 2003?

Answer: Nicole Kidman

The Young Victoria was played by which British actress?

Answer: Emily Blunt

How old was Coco Gauff when she first beat Venus Williams?

Answer: 15

In which year did Usain Bolt set his 100m in 9.58 seconds world record?

Answer: 2009

How many times had Rafael Nadal won the French Open by March 2020?

Answer: 12

When Michael Jordan played for the Chicago Bulls, how many NBA Championships did he win?

Answer: Six

Who did Forbes name the youngest self-made billionaire in 2019?

Answer: Kylie Jenner

Which Dutch makeup artist came out as being transgender in 2020?

Answer: De Jager

Performing Arts Trivia Questions

These questions shine a spotlight on the performing arts, i.e. theatre, musicals, and dance. After all, the show must go on.

Who played Anita in the first Broadway production of West Side Story?

Answer: Chita Rivera

In which US city is Broadway located?

Answer: New York City

What is the longest-running Broadway show?

Answer: The Phantom of the Opera

Which show is the highest-grossing production on Broadway ever?

Answer: The Lion King

In what year was Broadway established?

Answer: 1750

In which period did ballet originate?

Answer: Italian Renaissance

During which time of the year is the Nutchracker primarily performed?

Answer: During Christmas season

What French ballet term means ‘in front’?

Answer: Devant

Who was the greatest male ballet dancer of the early 20th century?

Answer: Vaslav Nijinsky

What is a plié in ballet?

Answer: Bending at the knees

Ready to make your own trivia quiz?

Cars & Sports Questions

Auto Trivia Questions

These trivia questions are all about the automotive world including its history and modern advancements.

Who is often credited with creating the world’s first car?

Answer: Karl Benz

Which animal can be seen on the Porsche logo?

Answer: Horse

Which companies are part of the Big Three?

Answer: General Motors, Fiat Chrysler Automobiles, and Ford Motor Company

Which company owns Bugatti, Lamborghini. Audi, Porsche, and Ducati?

Answer: Volkswagen

Which auto brand was the first to offer seat belts?

Answer: Nash Motors

What does BMW stand for (in English)?

Answer: Bavarian Motor Works

What or who is the Ford Mustang named after?

Answer: A fighter plane from WWII

How many parts (screws and bolts included) does the average car have?

Answer: 30, 000

Which car is often called the first muscle car?

Answer: The Pontiac GTO

In what year was the Corvette introduced?

Answer: 1953

Sports Trivia Questions

This trivia section deals with record-breaking athletes and the history and rules of sports.

How many soccer players should each team have on the field at the start of each match?

Answer: 11

When Michael Jordan played for the Chicago Bulls, how many NBA Championships did he win?

Answer: Six

Which Williams sister has won more Grand Slam titles?

Answer: Serena

What country won the very first FIFA World Cup in 1930?

Answer: Uruguay

In what year was the first-ever Wimbledon Championship held?

Answer: 1877

Which racer holds the record for the most Grand Prix wins?

Answer: Lewis Hamilton

Which Jamaican runner is an 11-time world champion and holds the record in the 100 and 200-meter race?

Answer: Usain Bolt

Which boxer was known as “The Greatest” and “The People’s Champion”?

Answer: Muhammad Ali

What sport was Jesse Owens involved in?

Answer: Track and field

Which hockey team did Wayne Gretzky play for in the ‘80s?

Answer: Edmonton Oilers

Health & Cooking Trivia Questions

Food & Drink Trivia Questions

This trivia quiz questions and answers section is all about mouth-watering cuisine from around the world.

What is the common name for dried plums?

Answer: Prunes

What name does deer meat go by?

Answer: Venison

What other name does “corn” go by?

Answer: Maize

What’s the primary ingredient in hummus?

Answer: Chickpeas

Which country produces the most coffee in the world?

Answer: Brazil

Which country invented tea?

Answer: China

Which kind of alcohol is Russia notoriously known for?

Answer: Vodka

What is the national dish of Spain?

Answer: Paella

Which European nation was said to invent hot dogs?

Answer: Germany

Which country is responsible for giving us pizza and pasta?

Answer: Italy

What is the main ingredient in the Vietnamese soup pho?

Answer: Rice noodles

What is the name of the Italian dessert made with coffee-soaked ladyfingers and mascarpone cheese?

Answer: Tiramisu

What is the primary ingredient in the popular Japanese dish tempura?

Answer: Battered and fried seafood or vegetables

Which popular soft drink was originally created as a medicine in the 19th century?

Answer: Coca-Cola

Which country is famous for its chocolate and is home to brands like Lindt and Toblerone?

Answer: Switzerland

Health Trivia Questions

These trivia questions focus on health, diseases, fitness, and the body’s systems, organs, and anatomy.

Which organ has four chambers?

Answer: The heart

In which body part can you find the femur?

Answer: Leg

What is your body’s largest organ?

Answer: The skin

What kind of cells are found in the brain?

Answer: Neurons

Which bone are babies born without?

Answer: Knee cap

About how many taste buds does the average human tongue have?

Answer: 10,000

What percentage of our bodies is made up of water?

Answer: 60-65%

Which element is said to keep bones strong?

Answer: Calcium

What does the acronym AIDS stand for?

Answer: Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome

How many times does the heartbeat per day?

Answer: About 100,000

Geography & History Trivia Questions

Geography Trivia Questions

These trivia questions will take you on a tour around the world. Just how much do you know about each country?

What is the name of the thin and long country that spans more than half of the western coast of South America?

Answer: Chile

Which American state is the largest (by area)?

Answer: Alaska

Which two countries share the longest international border?

Answer: Canada and the USA

What is the smallest country in the world?

Answer: Vatican City

Which continent is the largest?

Answer: Asia

Which of the Seven Wonders is located in Egypt?

Answer: The Pyramids of Giza

What is the capital of New Zealand?

Answer: Wellington

Which desert is the largest in the world?

Answer: The Sahara Desert (although Antarctica, which is larger, might qualify as a desert as well)

What is the name of the world’s longest river?

Answer: The Nile

Which city in India would you find the Taj Mahal in?

Answer: Agra

What is the largest island in the Mediterranean Sea?

Answer: Sicily

Which river runs through the Grand Canyon?

Answer: Colorado River

Which country is known as the Land of the Rising Sun?

Answer: Japan

Which African country is known as the “Pearl of Africa”?

Answer: Uganda

Which Asian river is considered the longest?

Answer: Yangtze River

History Trivia Questions

This section of trivia questions deals with three different periods in human history. How much do you really know about the past?

By what name were the Egyptian kings/rulers known?

Answer: Pharaohs

How many Pyramids of Giza were made?

Answer: Three

Who which queen was Julius Caesar involved with?

Answer: Cleopatra

Where did the Franks settle after defeating the Romans?

Answer: Gaul

How long did the Middle Ages last?

Answer: About 1000 years

Which religion dominated the Middle Ages?

Answer: Catholicism

In which year World War I begin?

Answer: 1914

In which country Adolph Hitler was born?

Answer: Austria

John F. Kennedy was assassinated in which city?

Answer: Dallas

On Sunday 18th June 1815, which famous battle took place?

Answer: The Battle of Waterloo

What event marked the beginning of World War I?

Answer: The assassination of Archduke Franz Ferdinand

Who was the leader of the Soviet Union during World War II?

Answer: Joseph Stalin

What ancient wonder was located in the city of Alexandria in Egypt?

Answer: The Lighthouse of Alexandria

Who was the famous nurse known for her work during the Crimean War and is considered the founder of modern nursing?

Answer: Florence Nightingale

What was the name of the ship that brought the Pilgrims to America in 1620?

Answer: The Mayflower

Music & Literature Trivia Questions

Music Trivia Game Questions

The music trivia questions below will test your knowledge about songs and artists across many genres. Stay tuned…

What was the name of the group Justin Timberlake used to be part of?

Answer: N’ SYNC

What was the name of the rock band formed by Jimmy Page?

Answer: Led Zeppelin

Which country did AC/DC originate in?

Answer: Australia

What genre of music did Taylor Swift start in?

Answer: Country

Who was the lead singer of the iconic ‘80s band, Culture Club?

Answer: Boy George

Which name is rapper Sean Combs better known by?

Answer: P. Diddy

Which musical legend is Jay-Z married to?

Answer: Beyonce

How many Grammys does John Legend have?

Answer: Ten

Which British girl group had a member by the name of Mel B?

Answer: Spice Girls

Who is often referred to as the “King of Pop” and is known for iconic hits like “Thriller” and “Billie Jean”?

Answer: Michael Jackson

Mythology Trivia Questions

How much do you know about the writings of the past? Test your knowledge about Greek, Norse, Roman, and Egyptian mythologies.

What is the name of the home of the Greek Gods?

Answer: Olympus

Which warrior’s weakness was their heel?

Answer: Achilles

Who was the messenger of the gods?

Answer: Hermes

What’s the name of the paradise warriors go to after death?

Answer: Valhalla

Thor was the son of which God?

Answer: Odin

Romulus and Remus were raised by what animal?

Answer: A she-wolf

The Roman God of War inspired the name of which planet?

Answer: Mars

What was the name of the Egyptian God of the Sun?

Answer: Ra

Anubis, the God of Death, had the head of a…

Answer: Jackal

Set throws Osiris into which river, after tricking him into a coffin?

Answer: The Nile

Ready to make your own trivia quiz?

Modern Literature Trivia Questions

This section of questions deals with famous modern authors and their books. Are you a bookworm? Let’s find out!

What author became famous for his six-volume biography of Lincoln?

Answer: Carl Sandburg

Who wrote “Old Man and The Sea” and is considered one of the greatest writers of the 20thcentury?

Answer: Ernest Hemingway

What Danish author is considered by many to be the most prolific fairy tale writer?

Answer: Hans Christian Andersen

Who is the writer of “Merchant of Venice”?

Answer: William Shakespeare

“Adventure of Sherlock Holmes” was written by which writer?

Answer: Arthur Conan Doyle

What is the name of the fourth book in the Harry Potter series?

Answer: Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire

The Hunger Games series was written by which author?

Answer: Suzanne Collins

Which country is Aesop’s Fables believed to originate in?

Answer: Greece

In Herman Melville’s novel “Moby Dick,” who was the loyal, reasonable first mate?

Answer: Starbuck

The book “Da Vinci Code,” was written by whom?

Answer: Dan Brown

Who wrote the novel “One Hundred Years of Solitude”?

Answer: Gabriel García Márquez

Who wrote the classic children’s book “Charlotte’s Web”?

Answer: E.B. White

What is the title of the classic Greek epic attributed to Homer, telling the story of the Trojan War?

Answer: The Iliad

What is the name of the protagonist in Jules Verne’s “Twenty Thousand Leagues Under the Sea”?

Answer: Captain Nemo

Who wrote the gothic novel “Frankenstein; or, The Modern Prometheus”?

Answer: Mary Shelley

Design & Fashion Trivia Questions

Fashion Trivia Questions

This group of questions explores everything from the history of fashion to popular fashion brands.

Who is seen as the most famous female American fashion icon of the 1960’s?

Answer: Jacqueline Kennedy

The American designer born in 1939 as Ralph Lifshitz is better known as what?

Answer: Ralph Lauren

According to the commercial, “what is the fabric of our lives”?

Answer: Cotton

Who invented the LBD (little black dress)?

Answer: Coco Chanel

Parkers, trenches, bombers and peas are types of what winter outerwear?

Answer: Coats

What fashion fad did the 1983 film “Flashdance” make popular?

Answer: Legwarmers

The fashion designer, Gianni Versace, came from which country?

Answer: Italy

When was the company Nike founded?

Answer: 1971

What animal is on Levi’s logo?

Answer: Horse

Which fashion brand made the “Genius Jeans” that became part of the Guinness World Records?

Answer: Gucci

What is the name of the red carpet event where celebrities showcase their designer outfits, often considered the Oscars of fashion?

Answer: The Met Gala

In the fashion world, what does “Haute Couture” refer to?

Answer: High-end, custom-made fashion

What is the traditional Scottish fabric pattern often seen in kilts and other clothing items?

Answer: Tartan or plaid

Which Italian fashion designer is famous for his colorful and bold prints, particularly in silk scarves?

Answer: Emilio Pucci

What is the name of the French luxury fashion house known for its monogrammed handbags and luggage?

Answer: Louis Vuitton

Interior & Exterior Design Trivia Questions

This section of questions will quiz you on everything from famous buildings to the furniture in your home.

What is the tallest building in the world?

Answer: Burj Khalifa

When did construction on the Empire State building started?

Answer: 1929

Who designed the Sydney Opera House?

Answer: Jorn Utzon

Between 1933 to 1947, the Hoover Dam was called what?

Answer: Boulder Dam

Where can you find the Petronas Towers?

Answer: Kuala Lumpur

Who invented the bidet?

Answer: Christophe Des Rosiers

What is the smallest size bed available in the United States?

Answer: Twin

Stripes, chevron, floral, and plaid are examples of what?

Answer: Patterns

What design style uses lots of sea/ocean themed items?

Answer: Nautical

What’s another name for a footrest?

Answer: Ottoman

Law & Politics Trivia Questions

Political Trivia Questions

The following questions are all about international politics. How much do you know about the ins and outs of the leaders and events that make the world go around?

Which American president was involved in the Watergate scandal?

Answer: Nixon

What are the surnames of the father-son duos who both served as US presidents?

Answer: Adams and Bush

How many presidents have been impeached?

Answer: Three

Before the laws were changed in 2000, how long was a French president’s term?

Answer: Seven years

Who has been the longest-serving monarch of the United Kingdom?

Answer: Queen Elizabeth II

World War I began with the death of Archduke Franz Ferdinand, of which country?

Answer: Austria

Donald Trump and which North Korean leader are known to trade threats over the internet?

Answer: Kim Jong Un

What was Mao Zedong famous for?

Answer: Leading the Communist Party of China to victory during a Civil War

Leader and political icon Nelson Mandela was from which African country?

Answer: South Africa

The largest political party in South Africa, the ANC, stands for what?

Answer: African National Congress

Trivia Questions About the Law

This portion of questions goes through legal terms, as well as some of the most popular court cases in history.

What is the legal term for a voluntary written statement made under oath?

Answer: Affidavit

What is the name of the classification of crime which is less serious than a felony?

Answer: Misdemeanor

A verdict is a…

Answer: Decision or judgment

What is evidence in court, where a person tells everything they saw or know?

Answer: Testimony

Who is the group of people sworn to make a decision/deliver a verdict in court?

Answer: Jury

What was the verdict in the O.J. Simpson murder trial?

Answer: Not guilty

How many homicides did Ted Bundy admit to?

Answer: 30

Ted Kaczynski was a former graduate of which university?

Answer: Harvard

Gregory Lee Johnson was convicted in Texas for what in 1989?

Answer: Burning the flag

Butch Cassidy was famous for doing what?

Answer: Stealing

In a courtroom, who is responsible for representing the government in criminal cases?

Answer: Prosecutor

What is the term for the agreement between the prosecution and the accused where the accused pleads guilty in exchange for a lesser sentence?

Answer: Plea bargain

What criminal organization, led by Al Capone, was notorious during the Prohibition era in the United States?

Answer: The Chicago Outfit

In 1888, which unidentified serial killer terrorized the Whitechapel district of London and was never apprehended?

Answer: Jack the Ripper

What is the legal term for the intentional false communication that harms a person’s reputation, often spoken or written?

Answer: Defamation

Animal Trivia Questions

These trivia questions deal with all things animals including anatomy, their scientific names, and more.

How long is the gestation period of an African elephant?

Answer: 22 months

What’s the scientific name of a wolf?

Answer: Canis lupus

What is a female donkey called?

Answer: A Jenny

Which mammal has no vocal cords?

Answer: Giraffe

What’s the fastest land animal in the world?

Answer: The cheetah

How many eyes does a bee have?

Answer: Five

Which animal symbolizes good luck in Europe?

Answer: Ladybug

What name is used to refer to a group of frogs?

Answer: An army

How many hearts does an octopus have?

Answer: Three

Do sponges have hearts?

Answer: No

What is the world’s largest living reptile?

Answer: Saltwater Crocodile

What is the largest species of bear?

Answer: Polar Bear

What is the only marsupial native to North America?

Answer: Opossum

Which marine animal is known for its ability to change color and camouflage itself in its surroundings?

Answer: Octopus

Which large sea mammal is known for its song-like vocalizations?
